slides.title: 3D Coordinate System
slides.content:
**3D Cartesian System:**
Every point in space is represented by (x, y, z)

**Coordinate Planes:**
- xy-plane: z = 0
- yz-plane: x = 0
- zx-plane: y = 0

**Octants:**
Space is divided into 8 octants.

**Distance Formula:**
Distance between A(x₁, y₁, z₁) and B(x₂, y₂, z₂):

**AB = √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)² + (z₂-z₁)²]**

**Example:**
Distance between (1, 2, 3) and (4, 6, 15):
= √[(4-1)² + (6-2)² + (15-3)²]
= √[9 + 16 + 144]
= √169 = 13 units

**Section Formula:**
Point dividing AB in ratio m:n:

**P = ((mx₂+nx₁)/(m+n), (my₂+ny₁)/(m+n), (mz₂+nz₁)/(m+n))**

**Mid-point Formula:**
**M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2, (z₁+z₂)/2)**

**Example:**
Mid-point of (2, 3, 4) and (6, 7, 10)
= ((2+6)/2, (3+7)/2, (4+10)/2)
= (4, 5, 7)

slides.title: Direction Cosines and Ratios
slides.content:
**Direction Cosines:**
If a line makes angles α, β, γ with x, y, z axes:

**Direction cosines: (l, m, n)**
where l = cos α, m = cos β, n = cos γ

**Important Property:**
**l² + m² + n² = 1**

**Direction Ratios:**
Any three numbers (a, b, c) proportional to direction cosines.

If direction ratios are (a, b, c):

**l = a/√(a²+b²+c²)**
**m = b/√(a²+b²+c²)**
**n = c/√(a²+b²+c²)**

**Example:**
Direction ratios: (2, 3, 6)
√(a²+b²+c²) = √(4+9+36) = √49 = 7

Direction cosines:
l = 2/7, m = 3/7, n = 6/7

Verify: (2/7)² + (3/7)² + (6/7)² = 4/49 + 9/49 + 36/49 = 49/49 = 1 ✓

**Direction Cosines of Line Joining Two Points:**
For line joining A(x₁,y₁,z₁) and B(x₂,y₂,z₂):

Direction ratios: (x₂-x₁, y₂-y₁, z₂-z₁)

slides.title: Equation of Plane
slides.content:
**General Equation of Plane:**
**ax + by + cz + d = 0**

where (a, b, c) are direction ratios of normal to plane.

**Intercept Form:**
Plane cutting intercepts a, b, c on axes:

**x/a + y/b + z/c = 1**

**Example:**
Plane with intercepts 2, 3, 4:
x/2 + y/3 + z/4 = 1
Or: 6x + 4y + 3z = 12

**Plane Through Three Points:**
Plane through (x₁,y₁,z₁), (x₂,y₂,z₂), (x₃,y₃,z₃):

|x-x₁   y-y₁   z-z₁|
|x₂-x₁  y₂-y₁  z₂-z₁| = 0
|x₃-x₁  y₃-y₁  z₃-z₁|

**Normal Form:**
**lx + my + nz = p**

where (l, m, n) are direction cosines of normal
p = perpendicular distance from origin

**Distance from Point to Plane:**
Distance from (x₁, y₁, z₁) to ax + by + cz + d = 0:

**D = |ax₁ + by₁ + cz₁ + d|/√(a² + b² + c²)**

**Angle Between Two Planes:**
For planes a₁x + b₁y + c₁z + d₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂z + d₂ = 0:

**cos θ = |a₁a₂ + b₁b₂ + c₁c₂|/[√(a₁²+b₁²+c₁²)√(a₂²+b₂²+c₂²)]**

slides.title: Equation of Line in 3D
slides.content:
**Symmetric Form (Cartesian Form):**
Line through (x₁, y₁, z₁) with direction ratios (a, b, c):

**(x-x₁)/a = (y-y₁)/b = (z-z₁)/c**

**Example:**
Line through (2, 3, 4) with direction ratios (1, 2, 3):
(x-2)/1 = (y-3)/2 = (z-4)/3

**Vector Form:**
**r⃗ = a⃗ + λb⃗**

where a⃗ is position vector of a point on line
λ is a parameter
b⃗ is direction vector

**Two-Point Form:**
Line through A(x₁,y₁,z₁) and B(x₂,y₂,z₂):

**(x-x₁)/(x₂-x₁) = (y-y₁)/(y₂-y₁) = (z-z₁)/(z₂-z₁)**

**Line as Intersection of Planes:**
Line can be represented as:
a₁x + b₁y + c₁z + d₁ = 0
a₂x + b₂y + c₂z + d₂ = 0

**Angle Between Two Lines:**
For lines with direction ratios (a₁,b₁,c₁) and (a₂,b₂,c₂):

**cos θ = |a₁a₂ + b₁b₂ + c₁c₂|/[√(a₁²+b₁²+c₁²)√(a₂²+b₂²+c₂²)]**

**Parallel Lines:**
a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ = c₁/c₂

**Perpendicular Lines:**
a₁a₂ + b₁b₂ + c₁c₂ = 0

slides.title: Sphere
slides.content:
**Standard Equation:**
Sphere with center (h, k, l) and radius r:

**(x-h)² + (y-k)² + (z-l)² = r²**

**Sphere with center at origin:**
**x² + y² + z² = r²**

**Example:**
Sphere with center (1, -2, 3) and radius 5:
(x-1)² + (y+2)² + (z-3)² = 25

**General Form:**
**x² + y² + z² + 2ux + 2vy + 2wz + d = 0**

Center: (-u, -v, -w)
Radius: √(u² + v² + w² - d)

**Example:**
x² + y² + z² - 4x + 6y - 2z + 5 = 0

2u = -4 → u = -2
2v = 6 → v = 3
2w = -2 → w = -1
d = 5

Center: (2, -3, 1)
Radius: √(4 + 9 + 1 - 5) = √9 = 3

**Diameter Form:**
Sphere with AB as diameter:
**(x-x₁)(x-x₂) + (y-y₁)(y-y₂) + (z-z₁)(z-z₂) = 0**

**Tangent Plane:**
At point (x₁, y₁, z₁) on x² + y² + z² = r²:
**xx₁ + yy₁ + zz₁ = r²**

slides.title: Exam Strategy for Analytical Geometry 3D
slides.content:
**Topic Distribution:**
- Distance and section formula: 2-3 questions
- Direction cosines/ratios: 3-4 questions
- Plane equations: 3-4 questions
- Line equations: 2-3 questions
- Sphere: 2-3 questions

**Must Memorize:**

**Basic Formulas:**
- Distance: √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)² + (z₂-z₁)²]
- Direction cosines: l² + m² + n² = 1
- From ratios (a,b,c): l = a/√(a²+b²+c²)

**Plane:**
- General: ax + by + cz + d = 0
- Intercept: x/a + y/b + z/c = 1
- Distance: |ax₁+by₁+cz₁+d|/√(a²+b²+c²)

**Line:**
- Symmetric: (x-x₁)/a = (y-y₁)/b = (z-z₁)/c
- Two-point: (x-x₁)/(x₂-x₁) = (y-y₁)/(y₂-y₁) = (z-z₁)/(z₂-z₁)

**Sphere:**
- Standard: (x-h)² + (y-k)² + (z-l)² = r²
- Center from general form: (-u, -v, -w)
- Radius: √(u² + v² + w² - d)

**Time Allocation:**
- Distance/mid-point: 30-45 sec
- Direction cosines: 60-90 sec
- Plane equations: 90-120 sec
- Line in 3D: 120-150 sec
- Sphere problems: 90-120 sec

**Common Mistakes:**
❌ Forgetting z-coordinate in distance formula
❌ Not normalizing direction ratios to get cosines
❌ Wrong sign in center calculation
❌ Forgetting square root in radius formula

**Quick Tips:**
- 3D formulas extend 2D by adding z-component
- Check l² + m² + n² = 1 for direction cosines
- For sphere center, change signs and halve coefficients
- Practice converting between forms of equations
